Introduction

Calcium is an electrolyte integral to bone health, muscle contraction, neuronal function, and blood clotting.  Approximately half the total calcium in the body is bound to proteins, primarily albumin, whereas the other half exists in ionized (free) form.  The protein-bound calcium serves as a reservoir, maintaining the levels of ionized calcium (ie, physiologically active form).  Therefore, ionized calcium levels are affected by changes in serum albumin, necessitating calculation of a corrected total calcium in patients with abnormal albumin levels.  Significant hypercalcemia and hypocalcemia may have potentially life-threatening complications.

Pathophysiology



Calcium balance is tightly regulated by vitamin D (

figure 1
) and parathyroid hormone (PTH) (
figure 2
).  Vitamin D, obtained from dietary sources (vitamin D2 or D3) or synthesized in the skin, is converted in the liver to 25-hydroxyvitamin D.  This intermediate is then hydroxylated in the kidneys by 1-alpha-hydroxylase (stimulated by PTH) to form the active 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol).  Calcitriol increases intestinal calcium absorption (main effect) and acts as negative feedback to reduce PTH secretion (by activating the calcium-sensing receptor [CaSR] in the parathyroid glands).



PTH secretion is highly sensitive and responsive (ie, within minutes) to changes in serum calcium.



  • When serum calcium levels decrease, CaSR reduces its signaling, leading to increased PTH secretion.  In addition to promoting calcitriol production, PTH stimulates osteoclast activity (increasing bone resorption) and increases renal calcium reabsorption (and phosphate excretion).
  • Conversely, when serum calcium levels rise, CaSR is activated, suppressing PTH secretion to allow calcium levels to fall (ie, decreased bone resorption, increased urinary calcium excretion).


CaSR is also expressed in the kidneys, where it helps regulate urinary calcium excretion.  When activated by high serum calcium levels, CaSR reduces calcium reabsorption, promoting urinary calcium excretion and helping lower serum calcium toward normal.  Various genetic mutations can affect CaSR in parathyroid and renal tissue, causing either hypercalcemia or hypocalcemia (discussed later).

Hypercalcemia

Presentation and etiologies



Depending on the underlying etiology, hypercalcemia may be asymptomatic (eg, found incidentally on laboratory evaluation) or symptomatic.  Symptoms of hypercalcemia (which are sometimes subtle) include bone pain, gastrointestinal disturbances (eg, peptic ulcer disease, constipation), renal colic, polyuria, and altered mental status ("bones, stones, abdominal groans, [toilet] thrones, and psychologic moans").  Etiologies can be grouped into increased bone resorption, decreased renal excretion, or increased intestinal absorption.



Specific etiologies of hypercalcemia include:



  • PTH-mediated

    • Primary hyperparathyroidism (most common) occurs when autonomously functioning parathyroid tissue (eg, adenoma, hyperplasia) escapes the normal inhibitory feedback effect of rising calcium on PTH secretion.  Hypercalcemia is typically mild.
    • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH) is a genetic disorder caused by inactivating mutations in the CaSR gene, where higher calcium concentrations are required to suppress PTH release.  Concurrently, the defective CaSR in the kidneys increases urinary calcium reabsorption despite elevated serum calcium.
    • Tertiary hyperparathyroidism occurs when chronic low calcium in chronic kidney disease (CKD) (discussed later) stimulates PTH release (ie, secondary hyperparathyroidism).  Prolonged stimulation causes parathyroid hyperplasia and autonomous PTH secretion (CaSR and vitamin D receptor downregulation), uncoupled from calcium levels (ie, tertiary hyperparathyroidism).
  • Nonâ€“PTH-mediated
    • Malignancy (most common):  Tumor secretion of PTH-related peptide (PTHrP) (eg, squamous cell lung cancer), osteolytic metastases (eg, multiple myeloma), or calcitriol production (eg, lymphoma) cause hypercalcemia (
      ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
      ).  Hypercalcemia is often severe.
    • Excess calcitriol:  Excessive intake of vitamin D or increased 1-alpha-hydroxylase activity by activated macrophages (eg, lymphoma, granulomatous diseases like sarcoidosis or tuberculosis) lead to calcitriol production, which increases intestinal calcium absorption.
    • Immobilization:  Prolonged immobilization (eg, quadriplegia) leads to increased bone resorption independent of PTH, as the lack of mechanical stress on bones favors net bone loss and calcium release.
    • Endocrine disorders:  Thyrotoxicosis can lead to thyroid hormoneâ€“mediated increased bone resorption.  Hypercalcemia can also be seen in pheochromocytoma (PTHrP secretion) and adrenal insufficiency (multifactorial).
  • Medication-induced
    • Lithium can increase PTH secretion through multiple mechanisms, such as shifting the CaSR set point for PTH secretion.
    • Thiazide diuretics decrease renal calcium excretion by increasing calcium reabsorption in the distal tubules.  This effect is relatively mild and usually offset by suppressed PTH (hypercalcemia is usually seen in those with coexisting primary hyperparathyroidism).
    • Antacid use (eg, calcium carbonate) in large quantities can lead to milk-alkali syndrome (a rare cause of hypercalcemia and metabolic alkalosis).
    • Analogs of PTH (eg, teriparatide) and PTHrP (eg, abaloparatide) used in osteoporosis can also cause hypercalcemia.

Evaluation



Abnormal total serum calcium levels should be repeated to exclude laboratory error (eg, improper sample handling).  Although calcium levels may be corrected for albumin levels, this result is more relevant for hypocalcemia (vs hypercalcemia).  Once hypercalcemia is confirmed, a detailed history should be obtained, focusing on supplement use (eg, vitamin D), medications (eg, thiazides), medical history (eg, malignancy, CKD), and family history (eg, FHH).  Measurement of free/ionized calcium can be helpful in cases such as hypergammaglobulinemia (eg, multiple myeloma), resulting in binding of calcium to excess immunoglobulins, increasing total calcium while ionized calcium remains normal.



In addition, it is important to identify renal impairment or other electrolyte abnormalities that could be contributing factors.  An ECG should be obtained in severe cases or in those with suspected cardiac involvement, as hypercalcemia can cause a shortened QT interval, prolonged PR interval, and/or widened QRS complex.



Serum PTH levels guide further diagnostic testing.  PTH-mediated causes are associated with PTH levels that are elevated or inappropriately normal (ie, high serum calcium should normally suppress PTH), whereas nonâ€“PTH-mediated causes have a low PTH:



  • PTH-mediated (ie, high or inappropriately normal PTH [escaping negative feedback])

    • Check 24-hour urinary calcium or urine calcium/creatinine clearance ratio (UCCR) (Caurine/Caserum)/(Crurine/Crserum)

      • Urine calcium >250 mg/day or UCCR >0.02: primary (or tertiary) hyperparathyroidism
      • Urine calcium <100 mg/day or UCCR <0.01: FHH
  • Nonâ€“PTH-mediated (ie, low PTH)
    • Check PTHrP, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, 25-dihydroxyvitamin D.
      • Elevated PTHrP:  Evaluate for solid tumor malignancy (eg, squamous cell lung carcinoma).
      • Elevated 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (active):  Look for sarcoidosis or lymphoma (eg, chest x-ray, CT of the chest).
      • Elevated 25-dihydroxyvitamin D (inactive):  Suggests vitamin D toxicity.
    • If all the above are normal, evaluate for other causes such as thyrotoxicosis, multiple myeloma, and immobilization.

Management



Mild hypercalcemia often presents with minimal or no symptoms, whereas moderate and severe hypercalcemia are more likely to cause significant symptoms (eg, obtundation).  Management options include hydration (+/- diuresis in some patients), calcitonin (opposes PTH effects; onset within hours but mild effect), bisphosphonates (inhibit bone resorption; onset within days but significant effect), glucocorticoids (reduce 1-alpha-hydroxylase activity), and dialysis (in severe cases).  Specific treatment depends on the severity of hypercalcemia:



  • Mild (<12 mg/dL)

    • Encourage oral fluid intake (6-8 glasses of water/day) to minimize nephrolithiasis risk.
    • Avoid aggravating factors such as thiazides, lithium (if possible), and excess vitamin D intake.
    • Regularly monitor serum calcium levels.
  • Moderate (12-14 mg/dL)
    • IV fluids (eg, normal saline) to promote renal calcium excretion.  Use loop diuretics cautiously after volume repletion in patients with kidney or heart failure to prevent fluid overload.
    • Calcitonin and/or bisphosphonates may be used in some cases.
  • Severe (>14 mg/dL)
    • IV fluids to promote renal calcium excretion and correct volume depletion (severe hypercalcemia acts as a potent diuretic).
    • Loop diuretics (eg, furosemide) may be given judiciously to augment urinary calcium excretion while closely monitoring for volume depletion.
    • Calcitonin and bisphosphonates should be given routinely.
  • Glucocorticoids are used in cases of granulomatous diseases or vitamin D toxicity to reduce calcitriol production.
  • Dialysis is indicated in severe or refractory cases, especially with renal failure.


In addition to lowering serum calcium, underlying causes should be addressed.  Because FHH is a benign condition not requiring treatment, it should be excluded prior to diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism and treating with parathyroidectomy (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).  Underlying malignancies should be treated (eg, chemotherapy) and patients with granulomatous diseases should be treated with immunosuppressive therapies.

Hypocalcemia

Presentation and etiologies



As with hypercalcemia, hypocalcemia may be asymptomatic (eg, found incidentally on laboratory evaluation) or symptomatic.  Hypocalcemia symptoms (due to neuromuscular excitability) include paresthesias, muscle cramps, tetany (eg, carpal spasm, Trousseau and Chvostek signs (

figure 5
), seizures).



Specific etiologies of hypocalcemia can be grouped into:



  • Low PTH:  Parathyroid glands cannot produce PTH (due to surgical, autoimmune/infiltrative conditions, or CaSR activation).

    • Parathyroid gland destruction (most common):  Parathyroidectomy or autoimmune damage reduces PTH secretion, reducing calcium release from bone (eg, lowering serum calcium).
    • Infiltrative disease:  Conditions such as metastatic cancer and hemochromatosis can rarely involve the parathyroid glands.
    • Activated CaSR:  Genetic conditions or cinacalcet (a calcimimetic medication) increase CaSR activity, which suppresses PTH secretion.
  • High PTH:  Parathyroid glands produce excess PTH to counter a calcium deficit (due to metabolic/inflammatory conditions or to PTH resistance).
    • Vitamin D deficiency reduces intestinal calcium absorption.  Common causes include inadequate dietary intake, malabsorption syndromes (eg, celiac disease, chronic pancreatitis), and insufficient sunlight exposure.  Vitamin D resistance (due to receptor mutations) is very rare.
    • CKD:  Decreased calcitriol production and hyperphosphatemia both lower calcium levels, stimulating PTH release; this condition is called secondary hyperparathyroidism (
      figure 6
      ), which is also due to other factors (eg, fibroblast growth factor 23) discussed in a separate article.
    • Hyperphosphatemia, in addition to CKD, can be seen in conditions associated with intracellular phosphate release from cell death (eg, tumor lysis syndrome, rhabdomyolysis).
    • Inflammatory:  Acute pancreatitis can lead to saponification (precipitation with fatty acids) of calcium in the abdomen, resulting in hypocalcemia.
    • PTH resistance is most often due to low serum magnesium levels but can also be due to a genetic disorder (pseudohypoparathyroidism) seen in childhood.
  • Medication-induced (associated with high PTH)
    • Calcium chelators such as citrate and EDTA (used as anticoagulants in blood products) can bind calcium, leading to hypocalcemia (eg, massive transfusion).
    • Loop diuretics cause renal calcium wasting by inhibiting calcium reabsorption in the loop of Henle.
    • Inhibitors of bone resorption (bisphosphonates, calcitonin, denosumab) inhibit osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption and calcium release from bone.
    • Phenytoin induces cytochrome P450 enzymes, leading to increased vitamin D metabolism and reduced calcium absorption.  It may also interfere with PTH action on bone.

Evaluation



Serum calcium levels should be repeated to exclude laboratory error and correct for albumin because hypoalbuminemia lowers total circulating calcium without affecting the metabolically active ionized calcium concentration (corrected calcium = measured calcium + 0.8 Ã— [4 âˆ’ albumin]).  Once hypocalcemia is confirmed, a detailed history should be obtained, focusing on medical history (eg, malabsorption syndromes, CKD), recent surgeries (eg, thyroidectomy, parathyroidectomy), medications (eg, loop diuretics, bisphosphonates), sunlight exposure and dietary intake (eg, vitamin D deficiency), and family history (eg, activating CaSR mutations).



Measurement of free/ionized calcium can be helpful in cases such as critically ill patients or those with acid-base disorders (

figure 7
).  In addition, it is important to identify renal impairment or other electrolyte abnormalities that could be contributing.  An ECG should be obtained in severe cases or in those with suspected cardiac involvement, as hypocalcemia can cause QT prolongation and T-wave abnormalities.



Evaluation should rule out an obvious cause, such as hypomagnesemia, adverse effects of medication, or recent blood transfusion (eg, citrate chelation); treating these causes typically resolves hypocalcemia.  Compared to hypercalcemia, further evaluation of hypocalcemia is fairly straightforward:



  • High PTH is usually due to vitamin D deficiency, which is confirmed by a low 25-hydroxyvitamin D level (typically considered <20 ng/dL).  High PTH can also be seen in CKD (ie, secondary hyperparathyroidism prior to progression to tertiary) and tumor lysis syndrome, which are diagnosed with serum chemistries and clinical context.
  • Low PTH (ie, hypoparathyroidism) suggests hypocalcemia is due to destruction of the parathyroid gland.  This condition can occur from direct injury to the parathyroid glands, inadvertent removal, or devascularization thyroidectomy (usually transient but can be permanent); autoimmune causes (activating antibodies against CaSR that decrease PTH secretion); and rarely, infiltrative diseases (eg, hemochromatosis) or genetic mutations.


This flowchart summarizes hypocalcemia evaluation (

figure 8
).

Management



Hypocalcemia management depends on the underlying cause and includes:



  • Calcium replacement

    • Oral calcium typically suffices for mild hypocalcemia (>7.5 mg/dL).
    • IV calcium gluconate (peripheral line) or calcium chloride (central line) is given for significant manifestations (eg, seizures, QT prolongation), severe hypocalcemia (â‰¤7.5 mg/dL), or an acute drop (eg, following neck surgery).
  • Vitamin D supplementation
    • Calcitriol (1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D) is used for rapid correction, and is also preferred in CKD because of decreased 1-alpha-hydroxylase activity.
    • Ergocalciferol or cholecalciferol (vitamin D2 or D3) is used for long-term management and prevention.
  • Magnesium repletion
    • Oral or IV magnesium sulfate is used in cases of concurrent magnesium deficiency (magnesium is necessary for PTH secretion and action).
  • Address underlying cause
    • CKD:  Manage secondary hyperparathyroidism phosphate binders, active forms of vitamin D (D2 or D3 cannot be converted into calcitriol), and dietary calcium adjustment.
    • Malabsorption syndromes:  Treat underlying gastrointestinal disorders (eg, gluten-free diet in celiac disease).

Summary



Calcium homeostasis is tightly regulated by the complex interplay between vitamin D, parathyroid hormone (PTH), and the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR).  Disruption of any of these components can result in hypercalcemia or hypocalcemia.

Hypercalcemia



Hypercalcemia symptoms include bone pain, gastrointestinal disturbances, renal colic, polyuria, and altered mental status.  Hypercalcemia can be PTH-mediated (elevated or inappropriately normal PTH) or nonâ€“PTH mediated (low PTH).  PTH-mediated causes include primary hyperparathyroidism (autonomous PTH secretion) and familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH) (CaSR mutations decrease sensitivity to calcium).  Nonâ€“PTH-mediated (ie, low serum PTH) causes include malignancy (various mechanisms including PTH-related peptide [PTHrP], osteolytic metastasis, and calcitriol production), granulomatous diseases (increased 1-alpha-hydroxylase activity), excess dietary vitamin D intake, and thiazides.  Management includes hydration, calcitonin, bisphosphonates, glucocorticoids (for granulomatous diseases), and dialysis in severe cases; underlying causes should also be addressed (eg, treating malignancy).

Hypocalcemia



Hypocalcemia symptoms (due to neuromuscular excitability) include paresthesias, muscle cramps, tetany (eg, carpal spasm, Trousseau and Chvostek signs), and seizures.  Hypocalcemia is usually due to vitamin D deficiency but is also often seen in secondary hyperparathyroidism with chronic kidney disease (CKD); PTH is high in both cases.  Low PTH is seen in hypoparathyroidism, such as following surgery (eg, thyroidectomy, parathyroidectomy), autoimmune destruction, infiltrative diseases, or activating CaSR mutations.  Management involves calcium and vitamin D supplementation, magnesium repletion when necessary and, in patients with CKD, active vitamin D analogs and phosphate binders.
